Schaefer Favorite in Three-Way Mayor Race
By MICHAEL HILL
Unless a major upset occurs,
William Donald Schaefer will be
• the next Mayor of Baltimore.
A three-way battle has developed for the Democratic nomination; it will be decided in next
Tuesday's Primary, but instead
of the splintering of votes coming among the whites, as some
observers had predicted would
happen in a three-way race, it
will be the black vote that is
split.
Next week's winners will face
token Republican opposition in
November's general election.
Schaefer's principal opponents are George Russell, the city solicitor, and Clarence Mitchell, a state senator who is U.S.
NEWS
Congressman Parren Mitchell's nephew. Both are
ANALYSIS
black.
It had been
thought that Mitchell would
withdraw from the race late in
the summer, clearing the way for
a direct confrontation between
Schaefer and Russell, but, charging that Russell is a sell-out candidate, "hand-picked by the
white establishment," the 31
year-old west Baltimorean has
stayed in and, despite a lack of
funds, developed into a serious
contender.
Financial statements filed this
week show that Mitchell has
spent about $50,000 on the
campaign while both Schaefer
and Russell have exceeded
$250,000 in expenses.
Mitchell, who has compiled an
enviable record in west Baltimore elections over the past
eight years, has aimed his campaign at the black community,
for the most part restricting his
campaigning to black areas.
. Image Trouble
Mitchell's campaign rhetoric
has been the most radical, with
the young state senator promising to be "the mayor of the people," getting government back to
the communities. But two things
have seriously hurt Mitchell's image, which he developed during

the civil rights struggles throughout the past ten years.
The first is a charge of housling . violations on some rental
properties which Mitchell owns.
The case has been postponed six
times in housing court and has
been in the headlines several
times this summer.
Mitchell claims that he has
been losing money on the proper ty, and that the charges
against him were politically motivated. Though it is true that his
case is one of a handful of test
cases, it has tainted Mitchell's
image as a "people-oriented"
candidate.
Propriety
In another revelation, it was
reported that Mitchell had given
a state senatorial scholarship to a
girl whose family makes in excess of $20,000 per year. Mitchell claimed that the sholarship,
worth several thousand dollars,
was payment for campaign work
the girl did for him, but the propriety of paying campaign workers with state funds has come
under serious question.
Though many other state senators were found to be giving
senatorial scholarships to political allies and friends, Mitchell's
grant did not help his image.
George Russell, on the other
hand, does not want the same
sort of image as Mitchell. He
worked his way up in the white
man's world and doesn't mind
saying so.
Within
While Mitchell was out demonstrating, 41-year-old Russell
was becoming one of the city's
top lawyers, then one of the first
black judges, then moving to his
present position as city solicitor.
He has portrayed himself as
the compromise candidate
throughout the campaign, his
signs proclaiming him to be
"The man for all." But his efforts at putting together a compromise ticket have brought
charges of sell-out from many
blacks, most vocally from Mitchell.
Russell's running mate for
President of the City Council is

James Lacy, the chairman of the
Board of Commissioners of the
Fire Department, and a man
with a less-than-liberal reputation. Russell apparently picked
Lacy over Walter Orlinsky, a city
councilman with a liberal background, who claimed that Russell had promised him the spot.
Orlinsky, who originally announced himself as a candidate for
mayor, is now running independently for President of the City
Council.
Castle Home
The presence of Lacy has
been part of the fodder for Mitchell's attacks on Russell. Mitchell does not have a running
mate, although he originally announced that he would field a
full slate of candidates.
Also present in the Russell
camp is the man who engineered
George Mahoney's "Your Home
Is Your Castle" campaign, and
several other representatives of
the white political establishment. While these people have
apparently helped to keep the
money coming in, they have
hurt Russell's image in the black
community.
Russell thinks that the black
people of Baltimore should look
to him as an example of what a
black man can accomplish. He
has no apologies for his lack of
activism, and, in one speech to a
black church congregation, he
said that his rise through the
system made him the man to
lead his people to the promised
land.
Cui Bono?
Russell had used his pride to
stubbornly resist the attacks of
Mitchell, whom he charges with
a lack of seriousness, pointing to
Mitchell's high absenteeism rate
in the state senate. Both have
scored telling blows.
No one is happier with the
running battle between the black
candidates than William Donald
Schaefer. Now President of the
City Council, the 48-year-old
Schaefer succeeded in avoiding a
battle among white candidates
when he got vote-getting right
-winger Hyman Pressman to run

for re-election as comptroller on
Schaefer's ticket.
Pressman wants to be mayor
in the worst way, and has said as
much on several occasions. But
apparently he realized the futility of splitting the white vote and
agreed to join Schaefer.
How They Do It
The ticket has maintained a
low profile over the summer.
Schaefer has used his position as
acting mayor during D'Alessandro's extended vacation to keep
his name and face in the news,
while Pressman depends on his
famous poetical ability to keep
his popularity up.
When Schaefer first entered
Baltimore politics fifteen years
ago, he was considered a liberal,
but in recent years has become
identified with the conservative
block in the City Council. This
undoubtedly helped him to consolidate white support for his
candidacy.
One of Schaefer's favorite issues is ecology. He was instrumental in getting the city government to start purchasing recycled paper as well as paving
the 200 block of North Charles
Street with an experimental asphalt which uses crushed glass
from recycled bottles instead of
rocks.
Who Stand and Watch
Other than that, his campaign
has remained fairly non-controversial, as he counts on the split
in the black vote to allow his solid white majority to carry him
to victory.
Schaefer resents the fact that
he will receive few black votes.
He has maintained his residence
in a Baltimore neighborhood
which has gradually become predominantly black in the past few
years. He doesn't seem to understand why his neighbors don't
appreciate the improvements he
has brought to the neighborhood
enough to vote for him. Schaefer, a bachelor, lives with his elderly mother.
Schaefer's only. opposition
from the right is coming from
Francis Valle, a lawyer who
seems to have spent some money

but made little headway in turning himself into a major candidate. Valle manages to get the
phrase "law and order" into almost every statement he makes:
his only forseeable effect will be
to take a few votes from Schaefer, but not enough to alter the
outcome.
Though there have been no
poll results announced, Schaefer
should win next Tuesday. Ross
Pierpont will undoubtedly be his
Republican opposition, but, despite gobs of money spent, the
November election is not expected to be much of a contest.
Sinking Sand
It would not be surprising if
Mitchell, riding a solid black
vote, showed up second, though
Russell has to be considered a favorite for that spot. The danger
in Russell's tactic is that the
middle ground that he has been
trodding may be swallowed up
by Schaefer, while the black

The presence of Lacy has
been part of the fodder for Mitchell's attacks on Russell. Mitchell does not have a running
mate, although he originally announced that he would field a
full slate of candidates.
Also present in the Russell
camp is the man who engineered
George Mahoney's "Your Home
Is Your Castle" campaign, and
several other representatives of
the white political establishment. While these people have
apparently helped to keep the
money coming in, they have
hurt Russell's image in the black
community.
Russell thinks that the black
people of Baltimore should look
to him as an example of what a
black man can accomplish. He
has no apologies for his lack of
activism, and, in one speech to a
black church congregation, he
said that his rise through the
system made him the man to
lead his people to the promised
land.
Cui Bono?
Russell had used his pride to
stubbornly resist the attacks of
Mitchell, whom he charges with
a lack of seriousness, pointing to
Mitchell's high absenteeism rate
in the state senate. Both have
scored telling blows.
No one is happier with the
running battle between the black
candidates than William Donald
Schaefer. Now President of the
City Council, the 48-year-old
Schaefer succeeded in avoiding a
battle among white candidates
when he got vote-getting right
-winger Hyman Pressman to run

for re-election as comptroller on
Schaefer's ticket.
Pressman wants to be mayor
in the worst way, and has said as
much on several occasions. But
apparently he realized the futility of splitting the white vote and
agreed to join Schaefer.
How They Do It
The ticket has maintained a
low profile over the summer.
Schaefer has used his position as
acting mayor during D'Alessandro's extended vacation to keep
his name and face in the news,
while Pressman depends on his
famous poetical ability to keep
his popularity up.
When Schaefer first entered
Baltimore politics fifteen years
ago, he was considered a liberal,
but in recent years has become
identified with the conservative
block in the City Council. This
undoubtedly helped him to consolidate white support for his
candidacy.
One of Schaefer's favorite issues is ecology. He was instrumental in getting the city government to start purchasing recycled paper as well as paving
the 200 block of North Charles
Street with an experimental asphalt which uses crushed glass
from recycled bottles instead of
rocks.
Who Stand and Watch
Other than that, his campaign
has remained fairly non-controversial, as he counts on the split
in the black vote to allow his solid white majority to carry him
to victory.
Schaefer resents the fact that
he will receive few black votes.
He has maintained his residence
in a Baltimore neighborhood
which has gradually become predominantly black in the past few
years. He doesn't seem to understand why his neighbors don't
appreciate the improvements he
has brought to the neighborhood
enough to vote for him. Schaefer, a bachelor, lives with his elderly mother.
Schaefer's only. opposition
from the right is coming from
Francis Valle, a lawyer who
seems to have spent some money

but made little headway in turning himself into a major candidate. Valle manages to get the
phrase "law and order" into almost every statement he makes:
his only forseeable effect will be
to take a few votes from Schaefer, but not enough to alter the
outcome.
Though there have been no
poll results announced, Schaefer
should win next Tuesday. Ross
Pierpont will undoubtedly be his
Republican opposition, but, despite gobs of money spent, the
November election is not expected to be much of a contest.
Sinking Sand
It would not be surprising if
Mitchell, riding a solid black
vote, showed up second, though
Russell has to be considered a favorite for that spot. The danger
in Russell's tactic is that the
middle ground that he has been
trodding may be swallowed up
by Schaefer, while the black
vote he counted on in a two-man
race will go to Mitchell.
Russell's running mate, Lacy,
could win the Council Presidency. There has been much campaign literature with just his
name appearing, indicating that
with his conservative background, he may be trying for
some of the white vote that
would otherwise go to Schaefer.
His position on the Russell
ticket may give him enough
black votes to win. He will be
fighting Paul Chester for the
black vote. Orlinsky could show
well, but there is a strong conservative white opposition in the
form of Joseph Curran. Pressman should take the Comptroller's Office without difficulty.
Real Winner
Perhaps the real winner next
Tuesday will be Tommy D'Alesandro, who decided last Spring
that he had had enough of trying
to solve Baltimore's problems,
and announced that he wouldn't
seek a second term, thus setting
up the current donnybrook. He
has been watching developments
this summer from the beach at
:Ocean City.
